bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, August 25, 1941

div1.p: Hench has selected the items which he thinks will help Wood to write her book on Reed. He offers to read her manuscript when she has finished writing.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, August 25, 1941
div1.p:
I have spent the weekend going over my rather voluminous data on the
yellow fever experiments and have selected what I think will be helpful to
you. I am sending some of it either by separate post or by express. I enclose
a list of the material being sent and also a list of letters, photographs and
papers which I have but which seem to me either relatively useless for your
purposes or which you can readily obtain on loan either from the Library of
Congress or from the Surgeon-General's Library. Let me comment about the various
items.

The letters of Dr. Lazear to Mrs. Lazear were loaned me by Mrs. Lazear
who permitted me to take photostatic copies. There are only three of them but
they are very revealing as they show that in the early stages of the work Lazear
had more faith in the mosquito work than any of his colleagues, a fact later
attested to in letters by Agramonte (see my W. and J. and my Cleveland talks)
and by Carroll (in his letters of June 23, 1906 to Kelly and of Sept. 26, 1906
to Latimer). I am sure Mrs. Lazear will not mind your having them as she gave me
permission to use them any way I wished. They have never been published except
in my own two papers and if you prefer to put onto me the responsibility for your
using them you can merely do so by citing my papers as reference. Incidentally,
my Cleveland talk will be published in the October Hygeia. These are the only
letters Mrs. Lazear ever got from Dr. Lazear mentioning his work. If you care
to, you might drop Mrs. Lazear a note asking permission directly to use the letters.
That may please her and give you an interesting contact. Her address is 116 East
Padre Street, Santa Barbara, California.

I am sure that Gen. Kean will have no objections to your using the three
letters he recently gave me--the one from Reed to Sternberg and the two from Reed
to himself (Kean). I have frankly “censored” both, not passing on to you certain
personal data critical of persons some of whom are still living. That data would
be of no earthly use to you in writing a book for children. I think the letter
of Sept. 25, 1900 from Reed to Kean shows Reed's kind spirit admirably and also is
a reflection of the wonderful personality of Lazear. May I suggest that, here
again, to keep everything in order, you phone Gen. Kean and get his direct per-
mission should you desire to quote the letters (I will send him a copy of this
letter).

I am on less safe ground when I lend you part of Miss Blossom Reed's manu-
script, that part which contains Reed's letters to his family from 1900-1901. Mrs.
Reed has long desired to publish them, connecting the letters with running comments.
She has been disappointed in having her manuscript turned down by at least one
publisher (largely because, I believe, the early letters are too personal for the
general reader and the connecting comments too brief). (Incidentally, is there a
possibility that your own publishing house might publish them? They would make only
Miss Laura Wood
- 2 -
August
a small book and one which could sell relatively inexpensively.) In preparation
for the Cleveland affair (unveiling of the painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”)
Mr. Kellogg borrowed Miss Reed's manuscript and asked me to read it over to select
a choice letter to be read by General Ireland at the unveiling. I was fascinated
by the letters--the early ones are so quaint (but very personal, being what might
be called his love letters to his fiance and later his wife) and reveal his wonder-
ful character, his ambitions, his ability to undergo hardships, etc. I do hope
you can get to read them. One of them, telling of the terrors of a long wagon
journey with his wife in Indian territory enroute to a new post is thrilling--
real pioneer stuff.

I was more interested, naturally, in the letters which concerned the Cuban
period. Some of them have already been published; others have not. They contained
quite a few data on disputed dates, his comings and goings, etc., so that when I
met Miss Reed I asked if I might copy those letters (from 1900-1901) to have as
background information but not for me to publish as letters. Naturally it would be
most unfair for me to publish what she has collected and hopes to publish herself.
She readily gave me that permission. Even so I would not let you have my copy
were it not that you have been unable to see Miss Reed yourself and were it not for
the fact that Generals Kean and Lawrence Reed have both given me their tacit consent
to help you in every way possible. I will ask you, of course, to respect Miss Reed's
wishes in this matter and will expect you to use the letters only as background in-
formation, and so that you may check your dates. More than that would be unfair to
Miss Reed. But I feel sure that when you finally get to see her she will be as
gracious to you as she was to me and will be glad that you are (as I am) honoring
her father.

You will find items 2 and 3 (p. 3 of the enclosure) very helpful--Gen.
Kean's memoranda re Reed. I am sure he will permit you to use it--much of it has
been published previously. But you will also ask him about this directly.

With a little concern I also send you photostats of two little known articles
which are very controversial, that by Donnally and that by Hemmeter. They are full
of inaccuracies and were written in an unhappy spirit--in an effort to laud Carroll
at the expense of his colleagues. Concerning the merits of this argument I will
waste no space in this letter. I ask of you to use them wisely and the main reason
I send them at all is that the one contains many of Carroll's letters therein with
some useful dates. But even the letters themselves contain some errors of fact.
One or two are obviously dated wrong (a simple thing to do). The special order #22
(page 159) omits Agramonte's name; the error was corrected in special order #122,
issued the same day but not cited herein. I have seen the original order #122.
The letter of Aug. 27, 1900 was of course written in 1901. There are certain names
misspelled here and there (e.g. Wamer for Warner, p. 162). Reed's movements are not
correctly noted in the letter of Sept. 18, 1900. The letter of Sept. 23, 1900 infers
that Agramonte was away when Lazear died, an inference contradicted by other evidence
I have. Carroll's letter of Sept. 28 saying “Lazear died tonight” is obviously
wrongly dated since Lazear died Sept. 25 (the bronze tablet at Hopkins nothwith-
standing:) I have a copy of the official death certificate, etc. These and other
errors were allowed to slip into the articles by Hemmeter and some of the statements
were later vigorously denied in a letter from Agramonte to Hemmeter (which is too
personal for publication).
Miss Laura Wood
August

I suggest therefore that you use only such data in this article which
you can confirm from other sources, and as you and I agreed in our previous
correspondence you are not interested in the unhappy controversy that occurred
after the great work was finished.

Of special interest is Agramonte's 1915 Scientific Monthly article. It
gives many interesting details not published elsewhere, but it too apparently
contains some factual errors. Remember it was written 15 years after the events
took place. There is some question as to the veracity of the story about Dean's
inoculation (p. 210) and the supposed conversation which Agramonte overheard. I
have no right to doubt that if this version was rather fictional, Agramonte had
some honorable reason for handing it out. But at least two times elsewhere Agra-
monte wrote that Lazear carried on the first two inoculations “unknown to the
other Board members.” So you'd better not reproduce that part of the story.

Permit me to ask you to read my report to Dr. Ramos (Cuban Minister of
Defense) in confidence. For reasons which I haven't yet found out (but suspect)
Ramos does not want this report to be published quite yet. Regardless of his
reasons I have my own reason for asking you not to quote it (except the allusions
to it and the brief comments I have already published in my Washington and Jeffer-
son and Cleveland talks). My reason is the simple selfish one that I want to
publish it myself soon in a medical historical journal. But I do want you to see
it because it contains a very carefully authenticated synopsis of “what happened
when” at Columbia Barracks and at Camp Lazear. I think this synopsis will be
helpful to you.

As you will see I am not sending you the originals or copies of the 10
letters of Carroll, the 2 of Mrs. Carroll, and the 9 of Reed which were part of
the collection of material which Dr. Kelly gave me. The reason is simple--I
doubt if they will be helpful. The 2 or 3 which Kelly thought of value he pub-
lished in his third edition (as noted herein). The others contain practically
nothing of value and nothing new that isn't published in detail elsewhere. If
you want copies I can have them made for you, either typewritten or photostated.
You probably know better than I do how much a typist would charge for copying
29 average length (1-2 page) letters. I regret that I would have to ask you to
pay for this as this is our busiest season (Aug.-Sept.) and we are swamped with
work. Our poor secretaries can take on no extra work in hours. But I frankly
believe it would be wasted money. Then why don't I mail them to you? As source
material for a book they are of little value (so little that Kelly didn't use
them) but as letters of “historical” or sentimental interest they are sufficiently
valuable that I don't want to trust them to the mails especially since they are
really not mine but on “permanent loan” to form a part of my growing collection.

The photographs cited you can obtain readily (I believe at cost) from the
U. S. Army Museum. If you want a copy of Camp Lazear and Bldg. No. 1 as we re-
discovered it this year I'll gladly send it with an appropriate description.

By all means consult all of the references on page 6 (enclosure). You
probably know of many of them already. Incidentally the story that Reed said,
“I salute you” to Moran and Kissinger is a legend and had no basis in fact. I
have that repeatedly and directly from both Moran and Kissinger. It's an appealing
story which you might repeat as a legend and perhaps handle as I did by quoting
the remark, “If Reed didn't salute them, he should have.”
Miss Laura Wood
August

I hope you will forgive me for having delayed so long in sending
this data. I do want to help you even though in a way I might selfishly
like to keep the data for my own forthcoming book on the whole story. But
beyond any personal desire regarding my own book I have the desire to honor a
gallant group of men and if I can help you spread their story so much the better.
Furthermore I have accepted much of the material I have been given, not for my-
self but as a custodian, the material to be available eventually to all critical
(but sympathetic) historians.

May I make this suggestion. I have found errors in every published work
on the subject, even a few in the official Senate Document so carefully supervised
by Major Kean. It is impossible for me to send you the (actually) hundreds of
pages of “original” material I already have, material collected by voluminous
correspondence and interviews. But I will gladly receive a copy of your pre-
liminary draft and go over it carefully to see if dates and deeds conform to
data which I consider authoritative. I do not propose to suggest that I criticize
your manuscript. I will merely tell you where you can check this or that point that
looks wrong to me.

In closing may I say that I too have had the same happy experience you
have had. If all retired or un-retired generals were as marvelous as the trio
Kean-Truby-Ireland “life would be beautiful”!

Please guard my photostats and reprints--in most cases I have sent you
my only copy. Return them at your “earliest convenience” but use them fully.
div1.closer: Best wishes. P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
